Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: A System-Level Framework for Operation and Maintenance: Synergizing Near and Long Term Cares for Wind Turbines

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Grant Opportunity for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) collaborative research project is to understand how a systems approach to operations and maintenance can enhance the effectiveness and profitability of wind turbines. Currently, operation and maintenance concepts and methods are predominantly components-oriented. This project will show that a system-level approach can yield a better trade-off between risks and costs, thereby optimizing an engineered system for overall economic value. The team will develop a way to measure a wind turbine system's holistic performance and tracks its decline over time at a system level. Establishing a system-level metric enables us to actively adjust a turbine's operation and realize a trade-off between near-term power production and system reliability. It also allows the PIs to weigh cost of maintenance against loss in power efficiency, leading to cost-effective decisions of maintenance.

The successful development of this new methodology ought to lead to cost-effective operation and maintenance of renewable energy productions, and reduce its overall cost and enhances their marketability (a key to the wind energy's 20percent-by-2030 goal and long-term sustainability). General Electric, a leading enterprise in wind energy, is a research partner of this project. GE's direct participation accelerates the application of the resulting methodologies to actual wind energy operational systems. The collaborative nature of this research and industrial involvement brings industrial perspective to the universities and is training our next-generation workforce in the new energy economy. The system-level concepts and methodologies, once demonstrated in wind energy applications, can go beyond and be applied to other power production systems, as well as automobile systems, aerospace systems, and marine systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While operation and maintenance are crucial tasks to ensure the reliability and service quality of virtually all civil and mechanical systems, a severe drawback of the current operation and maintenance practices is that they are predominantly components-oriented.  Albeit intuitive, components-oriented practices generally overlook the interactions among the components, and could therefore lead to either overly-conservative or overly-aggressive decisions in cases where one is obsessed with trouble-shooting at specific components while a system’s degradation is not caused by a single component. Addressing the operation and maintenance needs at the system level can lead to high payoff but doing so is scientifically challenging.  These issues are exemplified by wind turbines that are intrinsically complicated systems operating under constantly varying conditions.  Currently, the high operation and maintenance cost for wind turbines is a major hurdle to wind power’s marketability and competitiveness.

Motivated by this need, a university-industry collaborative team was formed, comprising of Texas A&M University (TAMU), University of Connecticut (UConn), and GE Global Research Center (GE GRC). The team’s research aims at establishing a new methodology, which measures a wind turbine system’s holistic performance, and then formulating a value-focused strategy, which synergizes near-term control and long-term maintenance to maximize the overall turbine output over its lifetime.  The focus of the TAMU’s research effort in on developing the system-level performance metric and the long-term care strategy. This report summarizes TAMU’s research outcomes, as follows:

(a) TAMU team investigates different candidates for system-level performance metrics.  The team starts with comparing a few existing system-level performance metrics for wind turbines, including availability, power curve, and power coefficient. The team made two major extensions to the existing metrics.  The first is to extend the single-dimensional, wind-speed-only power curve to a multi-dimensional power curve that controls for various exogenous ambient influences.  The second is to impose certain sharp constraints on the power curve, so that the resulting power curve is consistent with the requirements of the physical principles behind wind power generation. Doing so is a step forward towards a systematic incorporation of physical knowledge into data science methods and modeling.

(b) TAMU team applies the system-level metrics to quantify the impact of wake effect in a wind farm operation. Understanding and quantifying the wake effect plays an important role in improving wind turbine designs and operations as well as wind farm layout planning – all of these are system-level questions to be addressed. The team’s research outcome is again a data science model incorporating physical understanding and knowledge. The team believes that injecting physical knowledge into data science models is one of the fundamental reasons why the resulting model outperforms its purely data-driven competitors.

(c) TAMU team, by making use of a system-level performance metric, devises a multi-turbine, multi-component maintenance strategy. As a turbine ages, its power efficiency inevitably declines even when its components may still be considered sufficiently healthy. Such decline is intrinsic, due to small wears and tears aggregating, and difficult to be decided based solely on first-principle analyses of component reliability.  The establishing of a system-level metric allows one to weigh between cost of maintenance and loss in power efficiency, leading further to cost-effective maintenance decisions in the presence of stochastic weather and logistic constraints. Because such decline occurs slowly (in months or years), the resulting maintenance strategy is most pertinent to the long-term care of the turbine.

All the above-mentioned ideas are shown to make substantial impact on the originally posted problem and to advance the knowledge frontier in the area of system-level operation and maintenance for complex systems.  It is worth emphasizing that while the research team chooses wind turbines as the research platform due to the challenge and potential payoff, the roadmap, and new concepts and methods thus far developed, can be extended to other complex mechanical and civil systems.

The methodology developments and research findings of this project are at different stages of dissemination:  some were published, some are accepted for publication but will appear later; and others are in the peer-review process and subject to revisions before publication.

Students who worked on the project received training in the areas of data science and system engineering, production economics theory, and wind turbine technology.  These areas cover four disciplines:  mechanical engineering, industrial and systems engineering, econometrics, and statistics.  The research team presented their methods and ideas to not only their own professional affiliations but also to groups across disciplinary boundaries and to their industrial partners. Two undergraduate student were involved in TAMU’s team effort, one in the summer of 2015 and another in the summer of 2016. One Ph.D. student graduated at the end of the project.
